unit: Unit 7 | Inference for Quantitative Data: Means
title: Interpret Income | 1 of 2
question_text:
Last year, the mean annual income of residents in a small town was $\$49,382$.
This year, a random sample of $100$ residents in the same town found an annual income of $\$52,301$. A $95\%$ confidence interval was calculated and extended from $\$50,199$ to $\$54,403$.
Which of the following statements is correct concerning this interval?

choices.text: It seems likely that mean income for this town has risen from last year.
We’re $95\%$ confident that the true mean income of the town this year is $\$52,301$.
We’re $95\%$ confident the true population mean salary of this town last year was between $\$50,199$ and $\$54,403$.
We’re $95\%$ confident the sample mean from this year’s survey is between $\$50,199$ and $\$54,403$.
$95\%$ of samples such as this one would give an interval that captures the population mean of $\$49,382$.

solution:
While this is not a standard way to interpret a confidence interval, since the entire interval is above the population mean from the previous year, it’s likely that mean income has risen in this town from last year.

Explanation of Distractors

Choice 'B' is incorrect; intervals will always point to a range, not a specific number.

Choice 'C' is incorrect; the interval hopes to estimate the mean income for this year, not last year.

Choice 'D' is incorrect; intervals always hope to predict a population mean, not a sample mean.

Choice 'E' is incorrect. It is true that $95\%$ of confidence intervals would capture the population mean. However, the population mean is unknown in this case; it is certainly possible it has changed from the previous year's value of $\$49,382$
